channel.title: Bradley Manning, WikiLeaks' alleged source, faces 22 new charges
channel.description:
http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/03/02/AR2011030206272.html
This is the guy who allegedly leaked the classified documents to WikiLeaks. Now he's facing the death penalty.
To be honest, this whole situation with WikiLeaks is funny to me, simply because the United States is so protective of their information and this little issue occurs and now they're scrambling to hide everything that was released.

item.title: Bradley Manning, WikiLeaks' alleged source, faces 22 new charges
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

[quote]A citizen’s actions to help a foreign government overthrow, make war against, or seriously injure the parent nation.

Treason has many definitions. Manning’s actions didn’t injure the US, it injured the diplomatic position of the US. If that is treason, you should arrest the Bush administration too.[/quote]
Espionage I mean, thats the word I was looking for.

Read full topic
item.source: Bradley Manning, WikiLeaks' alleged source, faces 22 new charges

@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

A citizen's actions to help a foreign government overthrow, make war against, or seriously injure the parent nation.

Treason has many definitions. Manning’s actions didn’t injure the US, it injured the diplomatic position of the US. If that is treason, you should arrest the Bush administration too.

item.source: Bradley Manning, WikiLeaks' alleged source, faces 22 new charges

item.title: Bradley Manning, WikiLeaks' alleged source, faces 22 new charges
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

This isn’t treason. Treason is when you are engaged in war and leak info that directly results in the death of friendlies. Manning released information that showed to America, and the world, that America is being bumfucked by self-proclaimed patriots.

No, he exposed everything. Not all of it was something that was unfair etc. You don’t have to be in a war to be convicted with treason…

Read full topic
item.source: Bradley Manning, WikiLeaks' alleged source, faces 22 new charges

item.title: Bradley Manning, WikiLeaks' alleged source, faces 22 new charges
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Castration is usually done by injecting some chemicals. They can still have an orgasm, but they fire blanks. They don’t have little (if any) sex-drive left though, so I doubt they care about getting an orgasm in the first place.

This isn’t treason. Treason is when you are engaged in war and leak info that directly results in the death of friendlies. Manning released information that showed to America, and the world, that America is being bumfucked by self-proclaimed patriots.

Read full topic
item.source: Bradley Manning, WikiLeaks' alleged source, faces 22 new charges

item.title: Bradley Manning, WikiLeaks' alleged source, faces 22 new charges
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:82, topic:384700”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=480463.msg3521099#msg3521099 date=1299411947]

Pedophiles for example generally repeat their offenses after release on average of 80-90% of the time. That is ridiculous. If you had an 80-90% chance of dying every time you walked out to get the mail, you would never do it, which is why we should never release pedophiles once they are caught. And if you are never going to release them, there is no use in keeping them around…

Castrate them, so simple it is.

Your 80-90% number is wrong. 21% and you get a closer number.
Source: http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Castration+of+repeat+sexual+offenders%3A+an+international+comparative…-a019261213.
But it is to late to stay up any longer, 4:22 am.

That seems bordering on cruel and unusual, but if you just cut off all of their junk instead of killing them, I suppose that might be sufficient.

No, sexual drive will lead them to worse crimes.

Sex drive is a consequence of producing testosterone. If you chop a guy’s dick and testicles off then he doesn’t produce testosterone, and doesn’t have sex drive at all.
[/quote]
No… Ive heard of serial killers who kill because they can’t have an orgasm and it drives them insane.[/quote]That’s definately a mental issue then, because what Lothy said is completely correct.

Read full topic

item.title: Bradley Manning, WikiLeaks' alleged source, faces 22 new charges
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:64, topic:384700”]http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1362989/Wikileaks-whistleblower-Bradley-Manning-stripped-left-naked-cell.html

[quote]The U.S. soldier accused of leaking secret government files to Wikileaks was stripped and left naked in his cell for seven hours this week, his lawyer said.
Private Bradley Manning’s confinement conditions at a marine-run facility in Quantico, Virginia, have attracted criticism from supporters and lawyer David Coombs.
The intelligence analyst could face the death penalty after being accused of ‘aiding the enemy’ by leaking tens of thousands of confidential embassy cables to Wikileaks.

The 23-year-old’s clothing was returned to him a day later on Thursday, after he was forced to stand naked outside his cell during an inspection, Mr Coombs said.
‘This type of degrading treatment is inexcusable and without justification,’ he said. ‘It is an embarrassment to our military justice system and should not be tolerated.[/quote]

I fail to see how the US can take the moral high ground against dictators like Saddam Hussain, Gaddafi or Mubarak.
Also aren’t cruel and degrading punishments against the constitution?

And threatening a man who did nothing but blow the whistle on the lies that were being sold to the public about the war in Afghanistan with the death penalty? It’s not as if he was fighting for the enemy killing US soldiers or attempting to harm any American citizens. John Walker Lindh, who actually trained with Al Qaeda and fought alongside the Taliban only got twenty years. Leave it to America to give a violent terrorist only twenty years, but put a patriot to death.

How is this significantly different from what Ellsberg did when he released the Pentagon Papers during the Vietnam War? Both released documents showed that the public rhetoric of politicians did not match the internal analyses that said politicians were privy to. How can a democracy function when information pertaining to an issue of great public interest is systematically withheld from the populace by the government? I think bringing to light information pertaining to corruption withheld from the public by governments or corporations is the very definition of whistleblowing.[/quote]

Hopefully like Frell said they did it for a legitimate reason like to stop him from committing suicide. (though it would save quite a bit of hassle if he did) If not, then that isn’t right at all, I’d hate for some abuse thing to pop up and get him off from the consequences he should receive.

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:66, topic:384700”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=480463.msg3520745#msg3520745 date=1299380048]
Pedophiles for example generally repeat their offenses after release on average of 80-90% of the time. That is ridiculous. If you had an 80-90% chance of dying every time you walked out to get the mail, you would never do it, which is why we should never release pedophiles once they are caught. And if you are never going to release them, there is no use in keeping them around…
[/quote]
Castrate them, so simple it is.

Your 80-90% number is wrong. 21% and you get a closer number.
Source: http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Castration+of+repeat+sexual+offenders%3A+an+international+comparative…-a019261213.
But it is to late to stay up any longer, 4:22 am.[/quote]

That seems bordering on cruel and unusual, but if you just cut off all of their junk instead of killing them, I suppose that might be sufficient.

the bank:

You have absolutely no say in who dies and who lives, no one has that right.

That is right. Murderers don’t have a right to kill innocent people. Pedophiles don’t have the right to abusse, molest, and rape defenseless little children. And, as far as I’m concerned, once they choose to take those rights from their victims, they lose rights themselves. Like the right to freedom, the right to live in our society, the right to be called human, the right to life.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

I read about half of this thread and could no longer stand the ignorant retards of america posting in it.

Seriously, who the fuck do you think you are? You have absolutely no say in who dies and who lives, no one has that right. And if someone thinks that they have the right to make that call then they need to be punished, because its called murder. Whether you’re shooting a little boy or a cold blooded killer…its murder…and you deserve to pay for that. Certainly not through more death.

And whoever the fuck the idiot was who ran his mouth about how its the way it always was and shouldn’t change…hey bro guess what happened to slavery? The constitution is a fucking joke and needs a great deal of updating.

Fucking dumb ass americans. With your logic id bomb the shit out of your ignorant brainwashed country and laugh and say I did the world a favor because you’re all animals.

Read full topic

item.description:
@yakman wrote:

http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1362989/Wikileaks-whistleblower-Bradley-Manning-stripped-left-naked-cell.html

The U.S. soldier accused of leaking secret government files to Wikileaks was stripped and left naked in his cell for seven hours this week, his lawyer said. Private Bradley Manning’s confinement conditions at a marine-run facility in Quantico, Virginia, have attracted criticism from supporters and lawyer David Coombs. The intelligence analyst could face the death penalty after being accused of ‘aiding the enemy’ by leaking tens of thousands of confidential embassy cables to Wikileaks.

The 23-year-old’s clothing was returned to him a day later on Thursday, after he was forced to stand naked outside his cell during an inspection, Mr Coombs said.
‘This type of degrading treatment is inexcusable and without justification,’ he said. ‘It is an embarrassment to our military justice system and should not be tolerated.

I fail to see how the US can take the moral high ground against dictators like Saddam Hussain, Gaddafi or Mubarak.
Also aren’t cruel and degrading punishments against the constitution?

And threatening a man who did nothing but blow the whistle on the lies that were being sold to the public about the war in Afghanistan with the death penalty? It’s not as if he was fighting for the enemy killing US soldiers or attempting to harm any American citizens. John Walker Lindh, who actually trained with Al Qaeda and fought alongside the Taliban only got twenty years. Leave it to America to give a violent terrorist only twenty years, but put a patriot to death.

How is this significantly different from what Ellsberg did when he released the Pentagon Papers during the Vietnam War? Both released documents showed that the public rhetoric of politicians did not match the internal analyses that said politicians were privy to. How can a democracy function when information pertaining to an issue of great public interest is systematically withheld from the populace by the government? I think bringing to light information pertaining to corruption withheld from the public by governments or corporations is the very definition of whistleblowing.

item.source: Bradley Manning, WikiLeaks' alleged source, faces 22 new charges

item.title: Bradley Manning, WikiLeaks' alleged source, faces 22 new charges
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:55, topic:384700”][quote author=Moparisthebest] Blame everything on something or someone else! It couldn’t possibly be that this child molester or murderer is a bad guy, it’s just the fault of some disease he has that needs to be cured? If he serves his sentence, gets released, and does it again, it’s not his fault, it’s the system’s fault for not rehabilitating him properly?
[/quote]
Yes, thats what I’m saying. You should of course not let someone out if you think they are a danger to the society (A problem with the criminal system today, not only in US) and you should of course help them if you could.

I don’t believe in good or bad people, only in good and bad actions and that they are for the most determined by influence by other and your past. And if something in the past turned you into doing bad things, I’m sure you can turn them to stop such actions.

You are catholic right? It surprise me how rarely many religious people follow their scripture

[quote=Romans 12:19 ESV]Beloved, never avenge yourselves, but leave it to the wrath of God, for it is written, “Vengeance is mine, I will repay, says the Lord.”
[/quote] And if you didn’t understand my point, killing people is revenge…[/quote]

I don’t view execution of a murderer, rapist, or child molester as revenge. I view it as prevention of the same person committing the same crime again. I am catholic, and the catholic church is entirely against capital punishment, but I disagree with them on this point.

Pedophiles for example generally repeat their offenses after release on average of 80-90% of the time. That is ridiculous. If you had an 80-90% chance of dying every time you walked out to get the mail, you would never do it, which is why we should never release pedophiles once they are caught. And if you are never going to release them, there is no use in keeping them around…

Read full topic
item.source: Bradley Manning, WikiLeaks' alleged source, faces 22 new charges
